author: cargofe2
title: Multipurpose Cadastre Blockchain
description: The Multipurpose Cadastre has been implemented in Colombia, but it does not have a strategy to provide security to the information collected

f6_assessments.q0: This idea has promise, but it seems a little underdeveloped. They don't really have an idea in hand yet on how blockchain could compliment the multipurpose cadastre system in Colombia. They just want to try to find one and then propose it to local officials. That makes this proposal categorically relevant to this challenge, for certain. But it also makes it hard to feel confident about its potential for impact when the minimal level of brainstorming has yet to be done.
f6_assessments.q1: The previously mentioned underdevelopment of the proposal definitely affects its potential for success. The team isn't fully formed yet, and it doesn't list any needed cadastre experts, though the two team members listed have good qualifications. A little more legwork would go a long way for this proposal. It needs, probably, at least one more individual on board, though probably two (a technical person as well as cadastre expert), and I would recommend they hold a few brainstorming sessions and come up with a list of more tangible ideas for a future proposal.
f6_assessments.q2: Some more information on the "public process document" would be helpful. Will the proposers send out an email newsletter or keep the community appraised through some other means? If they better develop the roadmap with great details and more ideas, and follow suit with an auditability plan in parallel, this area would be stronger for it too.

f6_assessments.q0:
This is the kind of project that fits the challenge perfectly. The team seeks to build on existing strengths and make a permanent, public land registry.

Colombia has a lot of records which could be digitized, stored and registered on a blockchain. Cardano is very well suited for this. This plan could be repeated in other places. It fits the challenge well.
f6_assessments.q1:
The leaders of the plan seem well suited to the task. They are educated in relevant areas and have been working in the field for some time. The leaders have a strong grasp of the law, the history, the customs, and the desires of the people of Colombia. 

The budget seems a little light for the number of professional hours called for in the project.
f6_assessments.q2:
The plan seems workable and well organized. The timeline seems quick, but they have a lot of experience working in the area. 

There are clear milestones and measurable steps. It is almost guaranteed that they will succeed if funded. The primary measure of success is producing a document that determines the route for the implementation of the blockchain in the multipurpose cadastre policy.

f6_assessments.q0: This proposal sounds like lobbying to apply blockchain technology to the multipurpose cadastre to improve its security. Since it aims at protecting individual data in particular and national infrastructure in general, this proposal is suitable for the challenge. However, its impact is still a big question mark because the issues related to politics are pretty complicated and time-consuming. This proposal is lobbying for blockchain application in public administration only, but not a blockchain-based security solution. Thus, the broad application is possible, but it is vague as each country has its characteristics. The proposal also did not mention that it will advocate using Cardano's technology or security projects. (Rating given: 3)
f6_assessments.q1: Since the project has not mentioned a technical solution, I will evaluate the economic and political feasibility. The proposer claims that team members have extensive public policy experience. Also, one is the legal leader of Colombia's Multipurpose Cadastre. It can be a considerable advantage in lobbying, which requires political connections. However, I wonder why to ask for funding from Catalyst but not the Columbia government. Economically, a budget of 18,000 for three professionals in 4 months is quite reasonable. However, proponents should consider a longer-term plan. What happens after that? Lobbying is just one step in applying blockchain technology to public administration. Therefore, I recommend developing a completed, detailed outline rather than asking for small funds for each step. This way, the community will have a clearer view of your project, and it will be easier to support fundraising. (Score given: 3)
f6_assessments.q2: The implementation and solutions outlined in the proposal are somewhat general. However, publishing documents for the community to monitor project progress is excellent; the roadmap and goals are also specific. So I give it a score of 4 for the auditability.

f6_assessments.q0:
The proposal meets the challenge objectives by looking to improve and secure a fundamentally important part of Colombia, the national Cadastre register, through the Cardano blockchain.  The Cadastre register has a wide affect on anyone owning or working in jobs linked to real estate.  The proposal aims to investigate the potential of linking a national Cadastre to Cardano.  The potential exists to significantly improve the security of the register from outside manipulation, and potentially encourage dapp building on Cardano relating to linking the Cadastre register.

For anyone wondering, a Cadastre is a fundamentally important record for the operations of any country.  It is defined as a comprehensive recording of the real estate or real property's metes-and-bounds of a country. Often represented graphically in a cadastral map.  It includes details of property ownership, the tenure, the precise location etc.
f6_assessments.q1:
The team provides linkedin profiles and list experience in law and involvement in advising public policy.  The team does not appear to be experienced in any areas of real estate, Cardano, or any comparable project.  The team aim to hire the necessary specialists to enable the project to proceed.  A specialist in Public Policies for Development, a specialist in Multipurpose Cadastre and a specialist in Blockchain.  

Given no names are listed for these potential specialists, it would seem the proposal is waiting for funding before doing the research on who these people should be.  I would suggest the proposer gather potential specialists who are interested, and provide their names in the proposal so they can be evaluated.  This would then enable a judgement on the feasibility of the project.  As it stands I disagree the project is feasible without this critical planning.

There is no budget breakdown, only that the funds provided will fund the specialists.  I would suggest the budget should at a minimum include the amounts paid to each specialist.
The total funds applied for appears sufficient and the 4 month time period also seems reasonable.
f6_assessments.q2: The goal is well defined - being the investigation of integrating Colombia Cadastre into Cardano.  The proposal provides a monthly roadmap and says a monthly progress report will be provided to the public for each of the 4 stages.  Each stage is estimated to take 1 month.  The end deliverable will be a document “that determines the route for the implementation of the blockchain in the multipurpose cadastre policy.”  Therefore the project does provide sufficient information to be audited.

f6_assessments.q0: Your proposed solution is described in a moderately detailed manner, to be frank. You manage to give a lot of detail of your project’s characteristics and main objectives. However, perhaps you don’t pay much attention to your target users and their welfare. In this section, you have mentioned fundamental entities that need to be advised in your purpose, but you forget to identify who they are, exactly. Plus, which benefits could they receive after being given adequate information about the Blockchain system and how to access its use? Please put more words in them so that the community can see how great this project will support the users. Moreover, I think that from what you presented, this project is expected to complete its aim, which is to protect collective & individual data and properties constituted by the cadastral information of private and public real estate. But my advice is that you should explain why this project could accomplish its objective in order to convince the voters better. However, when it comes to your foreseen challenges, it’s obvious that they go with no certain solutions here. No matter what the risks are, the central point is that you need to find a way to address them effectively so as to avoid the rate of failure. Plus, even though you said that there is also a risk regarding the implementation of the proposal, you fail to explicate what it is, indeed. DOn’t let the problem vague like that, I suggest you elucidate this section better.
f6_assessments.q1: Concerning your work plan, your team is doing great when giving adequate information about each phase of the project implementation. Yet, I’m not sure your timeline is detailed enough for the community to follow because you only announce that each phase has an estimated duration of one month without specifying which months. Therefore, my recommendation here is to give your roadmap a precise and detailed timeframe, associated with central activities within each phase, especially as the community could acknowledge what your team will do to achieve these goals and deliver the solution successfully. Next, I can not deny that your budget breakdown is transparent and sticks to the plan, absolutely. What’s more, from all the background of two core members of your team that I have read (including the LinkedIn profiles that you inserted), I strongly believe that this project has a great ability to thrive and succeed thanks to their high competence in this field.
f6_assessments.q2: According to what you announced, the progress of this project will be reported publicly monthly by percentage of each of the four determined stages. I got this picture! Nonetheless, personally, I think you missed the important factor in this section, the tracking tools. If the monthly report is your method applied to follow the project, you should explain where these reports will be published. For instance, you can declare that the community could monitor the evaluation of your platform via reports published every month on Twitter, Facebook or Instagram. Anyway, your success metrics of this project are, unquestionably, close to your aim. This is the most concise content in this auditability section.

f6_assessments.q0: The proposal is well structured and written with enough information on the impact of this project. From my understanding, this proposal aims to provide a nation with a solution related to blockchain technology that helps to secure collective and individual data and properties which are constituted by the cadastral information of private and public real estate. I think this solution can bring many advantages to countries where dispossession and property invasions have already generated a lot of damage since it helps bring appropriate instruments for the formalization of property and to guarantee it. I also see that the team has foreseen 2 main challenges but it would be better if some solution for these two challenges can be provided to increase the reliability of the proposal.
f6_assessments.q1: There is a clear timeline providing specific actions that will be carried out through the estimated 4 months, which I find to be reasonable. And about the budget breakdown, i think it is pretty well explained since most of it is basically about paying salaries for 3 specialists, so we know who would earn how much and by how much it would be multiplied in terms of time, and other fee such as costs of meetings, graphics or travel costs will be assumed later by specialists. However, I suggest that some detailed information on 3 specialists should be provided to further increase the quality of the proposal. The team members are very committed to such activities. The core team only has 2 members but I think with their experiments, it seems enough to run this project. There are some reference links for verification purposes.
f6_assessments.q2: The team has provided information on how to audit the progress of the project, which is through a public progress document. Unfortunately, I can not find any clear final deliverables for this project. I suggest that some final deliverables and ways to evaluate them should be given out clearly. Besides, some key metrics with target or intermediate milestones can be provided so that the voters and the community can easily audit the developments of the project.

f6_assessments.q0: The issue raised by the proponent The Multipurpose Cadastre has been implemented in Colombia, but it does not have a strategy to provide security to the information collected. In many parts of the world over time, there are many changes such as (change of local government, loss of documents, natural disaster, war) affects information loss. This is a problem that needs to be solved, the proposal is suitable for this challenge. The proposed solution provides cadastral entities with an appropriate route to link multipurpose cadastral to the blockchain. aims to provide a country with a blockchain solution for the protection of collective and individual data and assets constituted by cadastral information of private and public real estate. The proposer should add more details of the solution so that readers can better understand the applied technologies. The risks of this project are particularly centered on the difficulty of access to the officials responsible for the multi-faceted cadastral policy in Colombia. There is also a risk associated with the implementation of the proposal that will be submitted to the government through the National Planning Bureau. This is a major barrier to applying blockchain to governments, the solution can build demos and organize discussions so that the authorities have more information to evaluate the benefits of blockchain.
f6_assessments.q1: The project will be implemented in 4 months and divided into 4 phases with specific contents that will create relationships with relevant or responsible people of the national planning task. The proponent should add specific objectives. The cost per month of professionals is estimated for an estimated period of four months. US$150.00X3X4: US$18,000.00 Additional expenses for meetings, graphics, or travel expenses will be borne by the professionals. The cost proposal has 3 experts, but the information about the professional skills identity is full of information of 2 people.
f6_assessments.q2: Metrics are stated but are difficult to measure or define (projects can be permanently tracked in a progress document that will be publicly available). The success of this proposal is to have a document defining the roadmap for blockchain implementation in a multi-purpose cadastral policy.

f6_assessments.q0:
Yes, this proposal effectively addresses the challenge by developing a framework how existing Cadastral (land registry) entities within Columbia through research and state interaction. Columbia already has a public multipurpose cadaster policy but is identifying ways to allow it to be updated, reliable, and consistent with the real estate system and to make it digital and interoperable with other information systems. 

The team plans to engage those entities working in the space to identify opportunities for integrating the blockchain, for enhanced security and resiliency of the system. Those countries that adopt this technology from the outset are more likely to have solutions that are durable and cannot be changed at the whim of a government or military change of power. While the team is looking at Colombia for their use cases, one could imagine there would be many other jurisdictions that could benefit from such an analysis. 

The introduction of a blockchain solution for cadaster registries would not only provide benefits to the individual through a persistent record of ownership overtime, but it would also likely have benefits for the state apparatus, through large cost saving and increased efficiency. 

In order to get full marks, I would have liked to see some discussion on the current desire of the Colombian state to work towards a blockchain solution. Is there a welcoming sentiment for these solutions or are they seen as undermining to the overall regime? If the state is not inclined to pursue this approach then the impact would be significantly reduced.
f6_assessments.q1:
Yes, given the experience and plan presented it is likely this proposal will be implemented successfully. The team lays out their plan over a four month period with four different stages at each month starting with approaching the appropriate-level government contacts, to doing a analysis on the current state of play, to developing a blockchain solution within the updating of Colombia's cadaster, to the final stage where they will present their proposal to the state authorities in charge. 

It is a little difficult to know the full feasibility of the project as there is not really a way to know what is entailed at each stage, particularly as it is dependent on agreement from the state to participate. If the state is not willing to engage the project team, there is a high chance it won't be implemented successfully. 

Nonetheless, the team's credentials do inspire confidence in the proposal and may mitigate the previous point due to their proximity within the system they are trying to change. Specifically, the team notes "One of the proponents was the legal leader of the project for the implementation of the Multipurpose Cadastre in Colombia at the National Planning Department and the group has extensive experience in public policy". This implies that the team may already have the necessary connections into the area it wants to enter, but this could be clearer and would improve overall feasibility.
f6_assessments.q2:
Yes, the information provided is sufficient to audit the progress and the success of the proposal. The team commits to providing an evergreen project report that shows the progress of the proposal through the stages, however what format and through what venues this will happen is not identified. While voters can audit the proposal's success through a yes/no answer to "did the team complete a document that identifies how a blockchain solution could be implemented in the Colombian cadaster" this is seemingly the only way. 

I would have liked to see more discussion about including auditing throughout the proposal, from issue identification to solution proposals. What I am unsure about here is how the team will confirm that their findings of the research and the solution proposed are verified and feasible in this context. Given the team's listed experience I would assume they have experience with peer-review processes but they do not seem to be included here. I would encourage the team to include this information or more explicit success measurements and key indicators by which the community could guage success.
